Epistemology and Philosophy of Science
4. Epistemology and Philosophy of Science

Bolzano strove for objectivity in “pure logic” in the
sense that the concepts and laws of logic are mind-independent. In
“applied logic”, in particular in epistemology, however,
we have to take into account also the real, i.e., empirical,
conditions of the human mind and thinking according to Bolzano (WL I,
66 f.). Nevertheless, he defined  the basic concepts of
epistemology primarily on the level of ideas and propositions. This
gave rise to the misunderstanding that his investigations are
worthless for epistemology proper or even that there is no
epistemology proper at all in Bolzano’s work. The fact that this
is by no means the case, will — hopefully — emerge from
the following survey of Bolzano’s epistemology.
